There was no Contingency Plan developed or documented by the Licensee at the time of the inspection. A written plan
should have been in place by 7/5/22.
Per this Section, exhibitors must develop, document, and follow an appropriate plan to provide for the humane handling,
treatment, transportation, housing, and care of their animals in the event of an emergency or disaster (one which could
reasonably be anticipated and expected to be detrimental to the good health and well-being of the animals in their
possession). The contingency plan requirement ensures that the animals receive proper care during emergency
situations. Correct by 6/1/23.

The back wooden walls of the two chinchilla exhibit enclosures (4 chinchillas) had several areas of damage from the
chinchillas chewing on the walls. These areas were rough and irregular, and the unpainted interior layer of the wall board
was exposed.
Per this Section, indoor housing facilities shall be structurally sound, be maintained in good repair, and protect the
animals from injury. Wooden surfaces that the animals have chewed on have uneven, rough, or irregular surfaces that
may cause an injury to the tongue/soft tissues of the mouth and/or may not be effectively sanitized. The back walls of the
two chinchilla enclosures need to be repaired or replaced. Correct by 6/1/23.
This inspection and exit briefing were conducted with facility representatives.
*END OF REPORT*
